question: A simple pendulum has a period of 2 seconds on Earth. If this pendulum is taken to the Moon, where the acceleration due to gravity is about 1/6 that on Earth, what would be its new period?
solution: The period of a simple pendulum is given by the formula T = 2π√(L/g), where L is the length of the pendulum and g is the acceleration due to gravity. The period is directly proportional to the square root of L/g. If g is reduced to 1/6 of its value on Earth, then the new period will be √6 times the original period. Since the original period was 2 seconds, the new period on the Moon would be 2√6 seconds.
